proof:
Proof of Lemma 12. Let $E'_K$ be the set of edges in the kernel whose corresponding induced path in G contains at least one edge from $E'$. Notice this does not increase the number of edges, i.e. $|E'_K| \le |E'|$. Also, from Lemma 40, $|E_c| \le (1 + e^{-d/3})|E_K|$, thus
$$
|E'_K| \le \frac{|E_K|}{144} (2\theta - 2e^{-d/3})(1 + e^{-d/3}) < \frac{|E_K|}{144}
$$
Note that for all $d$ large enough, $\frac{1}{100} \le 2e^{-d/3}$, thus $|E'| \le \frac{|E_c|}{144}(2\theta - 2e^{-d/3})$. Hence we can apply Lemma 45 to get that $(V_K, E_K \setminus E'_K)$ contains a giant component of total degree at least
$$
(1 - (\theta - e^{-d/3})(1+e^{-d/3})) \mathrm{deg}_K(V_K) \ge \frac{1 - (\theta - e^{-d/3})(1+e^{-d/3})}{1+e^{-d/3}} \mathrm{degg}(V_c) = (1 - (\theta - e^{-d/3}))\mathrm{degg}(V_c) \ge (1-\theta)\mathrm{degg}(V_c).
$$
To finish, we note that vertices of this component are also in the same component of $(V_c, E_c \setminus E')$, their degrees do not decrease, and hence there is a component of $(V_c, E_c \setminus E')$ with total degree $\ge (1 - \theta)\mathrm{degg}(V_c)$. The lemma follows.
